questions.text: A patient of supracondylar fracture of humerus is unable to flex his inter-phalangeal joint of thumb. Which nerve is most likely injured ? (AIIMS may 2018).
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Median nerve is injured in carpal tunnel syndrome Option B-radial nerve is injured in posteromedial displacement of distal fragment of supracondylar fracture of humerus. Option C-Ulnar nerve is injured in anterior displacement of distal fragment of supracondylar fracture of humerus. Option D-The most common nerve injured in supracondylar fracture of humerus is anterior interosseous nerve.AIN supplies flexor pollicis longus,hence in case of it`s injury,patient won`t be able to flex his interphalangeal joint of thumb.

questions.text: Most common complication of mid shaft humerus fracture is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Radial nerve is M/C injured in fracture shaft humerus(Spiral groove injury). Option B-Median nerve is injured in carpal tunnel syndrome. Option C-Non union and Malunion are not common complications of midshaft fracture of humerus.

questions.text: Proximal humerus fracture which has maximum chances of avascular necrosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B,C,D-As the number of parts increases, chances of AVN also increase, hence 4 part fracture has maximum chances of AVN among the given options.

questions.text: A child presents with the following deformity most common etiology is? (AIIMS may 2018)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The given image shows cubitus varus/gunstock deformity in right limb of patient.it is seen in S/C fracture of humerus. Option B- lateral condyle fracture shows cubitus valgus. Option C-radial head dislocation do not present with cubitus varus. Option C-Monteggia fracture is fracture of ulna and it also do not present with cubitus varus.

choices.text: Closed reduction of fracture and look for reappearance of pulse
Closed reduction, above elbow slab plaster and observe
Open reduction and internal fixation of fracture.

questions.text: In Supracondylar fracture of humerus in children if the radial pulse is absent, what is next line of management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Emergency brachial artery exploration is not done immediately.It can be done if pulse is not appearing despite closed reduction. Option B-Do immediate Closed reduction and flex the elbow till the pulse reappears, and then immobilise the elbow in that position. Option C-We have to again check pulse after closed reduction,instead of directly jumping to slab plaster. Option D-we do closed reduction and not open reduction.

questions.text: Pointing index is a complication seen in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-lateral condyle of humerus causes cubitus valgus. Option B-M/C nerve injured in supracondylar fracture of humerus is AIN>Median>radial > ulnar. AIN (branch of median nerve) injury will lead to pointing index sign . Option C-axillary nerve is commonly injured in shoulder dislocation. Option D-radial nerve is injured in fracture shaft of humerus.

questions.text: All of the following are complications of supracondylar fracture of humerus in children except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Supracondylar fracture is the M/C fracture to cause compartment syndrome in children. Option B-Myositis ossificans is also a known complication of Supracondylar fracture. Option C-Supracondylar fracture malunites and can cause cubitus varus. Option D-As stated above,-Supracondylar fracture malunites and lateral condyle fracture goes into non-union, if unmanaged.

questions.text: Malunited Supracondylar fracture humerus causes:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Cubitus varus due to malunited S/C fracture is a static deformity. Option B-whereas cubitus valgus due to lateral condyle fracture non-union is a progressive deformity. Option C-Cubitus varus occurs due to malunited S/C fracture(not cubitus valgus). Option D-shortening is not seen in S/C fracture.

questions.text: In supracondylar fracture humerus, treatment is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-If fracture cannot be reduced by closed reduction, then open surgery may be required. Option B-Ideal treatment is closed reduction and K wire fixation, with an above elbow POP slab. Option C-Excision is not a treatment option in S/C fracture humerus. Option D-we apply above elbow slab as the fracture is in humerus.

questions.text: A six-year-old child presented with a valgus deformity at his right elbow since 3 years that is gradually progressive. He has a history of cast applied for 6 weeks after fall on outstretched hand 3 year back. The probable fracture was?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-This is a case of fracture lateral condyle humerus which was managed conservatively, leading to non-union in child and thus a valgus deformity developed at elbow(progressive deformity). Option B-S/C fracture causes cubitus varus/gunstock deformity. Option C-poserior dislocation of elbow do not commonly present with cubitus valgus. Option D-Lateral condylar fracture(not medial) presents with cubitus valgus.

questions.text: Most common complication of lateral condyle humerus fracture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Supracondylar fracture goes into malunion. Option B-lateral condyle fracture goes into non-union. Option C-volkmann ischemic contracture is seen in Supracondylar fracture. Option D-median nerve injury is not seen in lateral condyle fracture.

choices.text: Fracture of both bones of forearm

questions.text: Which fracture requires open reduction in children?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B,C-can be managed conservatively. Option D-Lateral condyle fracture is aka fracture of necessity, as it is always managed surgically (Open reduction and fixation with K wire).

questions.text: Tardy ulnar nerve palsy seen in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Medial condyle humerus fracture is less common. Option B-Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is seen in valgus deformity due to traction in ulnar nerve because of excessive valgus. Option C-Rarely Malunited fracture S/C humerus ma also lead to tardy ulnar nerve palsy. Option D-Fracture shaft of humerus causes radial nerve palsy.

questions.text: Which is the earliest reliable sign of compartment syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Stretch pain is the earliest reliable sign Option B-pulselessness is the least reliable sign. Option C,D-Paraesthesia and Pallor are not the earliest sign of compartment syndrome.

questions.text: Use of this splint is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Turn buckle splint is used in VIC to prevent contractures. Option B-cockup splint is used in Radial nerve injury. Option C-Myositis ossificans is ultimately treated by surgical excision. Option D-knuckle bender splint is used in treatment of Claw hand.

questions.text: Most common cause of acute compartment syndrome in children is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The most common cause of compartment syndrome in children is supracondylar humerus fracture while in adults it is proximal tibia fracture. Overall compartment syndrome is more common in leg and tibia fractures are the commonest cause.

questions.text: In Volkmann’s contracture, which artery is involved?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Volkmann ischemic contracture is classically associated with a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. However, any fracture of the arm or elbow may result in this deformity.Brachial artery is most commonly involved.Volkmann contracture develops when there is sustained ischemic damage to the muscles. Diminished blood flow to the forearm, causing ischemia.Contractures eventually develop due to prolonged myonecrosis, which stimulates fibroblastic proliferation.

questions.text: Dye is injected in one of the extremities in a child and is followed by pain and swelling of upper limb, Paresthesias of fingers, stretch pain and normal peripheral pulses, management is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Aspiration is not used in management of compartment syndrome. Option B-Anti- Inflammatory can be given but are not the mainstay of management. Option C-In cases of impending compartment syndrome, observation has a role, but not in established compartment syndrome. Option D-This is case of compartment syndrome , and is managed by fasciotomy to relieve pressure.

questions.text: Most common site of myositis ossificans?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Elbow is the Most common site of myositis ossificans as occurs in case of supracondylar fracture humerus.

questions.text: Treatment of Acute Myositis Ossificans is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B-Active mobilization and Passive mobilization can rather aggravate Myositis Ossificans. Option C-Infra Red Therapy is not used in treatment of Myositis Ossificans. Option D-Immobilisation / rest is the most important treatment in acute period of Myositis Ossificans.

questions.text: Which of the following findings appear late in compartment syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Paralysis is typically a late sign of compartment syndrome, indicating severe nerve damage due to prolonged elevated pressure in the affected compartment. By the time paralysis occurs, irreversible ischemia and nerve injury have often taken place, making this a sign of a more advanced stage of compartment syndrome. Option A. Pallor: Pallor can appear early in compartment syndrome, as decreased blood flow causes the affected area to lose its normal color. It may happen before pulselessness or paralysis and is an important early indicator. Option B. Pulselessness: While pulselessness may occur in severe cases of compartment syndrome, it is not a reliable sign. In fact, pulse may still be palpable in early stages of compartment syndrome, and it is possible to have a pulse even with elevated compartment pressures. Thus, pulselessness should not be used alone for diagnosis. Option D. Pain on passive stretch: This is one of the earliest and most specific signs of compartment syndrome. The pain arises because of muscle ischemia when the muscles are stretched due to increased pressure in the compartment. It’s a critical finding for early detection and intervention.

questions.text: Identify the nerve injury and MC complication of this condition if left untreated. X-ray is given below.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) It is a fracture of lateral condyle of humerus. m/c complication is lateral bony spur formation m/c complication requiring treatment is nonunion [cubitus valgus] m/c nerve injury: tardy ulnar nerve palsy.
